results.title: Inner city, by West Coast artist Michael McMillen: a film
results.brief_description: The neglected exterior quality of Inner City is an environmental sculpture which takes us to the veiled border between illusion and reality. Michael McMillen began building Inner City in 1975, finishing it in Nov 1977 for the opening of his one-man exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

results.title: Innamorati
results.brief_description:
Assembled from family photographs, home movies and background music, Roberta Ciabarra narrates a poignant story of her parent’s courtship and unusual marriage as they migrate separately to Australia to establish a new life.

First created as part of the pilot 3 day digital storytelling workshop conducted at Cinemedia by Nina Mullen and Joe Lambert from the Center for Digital Storytelling, Berkeley, CA.

results.title: Inland with Sturt
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson, Australian National Film Board and Hugh McInnes
results.brief_description: The historic journey of explorer Charles Sturt down the Murrumbidgee and Murray Rivers opened up one of the world’s most prosperous fruit and cereal growing areas. The re-enactment of the trip by a group of young Australians, as recorded in this film, was one of the highlights of the Australian Commonwealth Jubilee Celebrations.

results.title: Inland with McDouall Stuart
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Men of stamina”.
The first part of the film tells the story of Stuart’s three attempts, the last successful, to cross the continent from south to north. The second part describes today in the Northern Territory. A description of the country Stuart opened up suggesting that his prophecies are coming true.

results.title: Inkle looms
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson, John Gray and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Weaving”.
An instructional film on weaving for both beginners and more advanced weavers. An inkle loom is used to make narrow braid or bands.

results.title: Injury in sport
results.creator_credit: Newfilms and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Using live-action, animation and diagrams, this film clearly outlines many forms of sporting injuries to the bones, joints, ligaments, tendons, muscles and head. Briefly covers treatment and preventive measures.

results.title: Injection errors
results.brief_description: Expresses some of the mistakes which can be made in giving injections and outlines simple steps which can prevent them. In particular, the route, size and frequency of injections must be planned and allergy, infection and drug interaction considered.

results.title: Inje: lost in translation
results.creator_credit: Seahorse Productions, Australian Film Commission, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Pippa Bailey
results.brief_description: A very interesting documentary about an artistic collaboration between Australia and Bulgaria involving the Hildegard Theatre Company from Melbourne, Australia and a group of Bulgarian actors led by avant garde theatre director Vaskressia Vicharova in Bulgaria. The Hildegard Theatre Company’s passion for Bulgarian folklore inspired them to initiate a joint production of bi-lingual theatre to travel Australia during 1996 - their choice of performance being the heroic legend of “Inje” a fearless war-lord and bandit. Angela Campbell and Bagryana Popov, artistic directors for Hildegard, and David Wicks, theatre director, headed the Australian company in Bulgaria where the collaboration suffered enormously during the rehearsal process. Differences in interpretation of the narrative, directing methods, and acting methods gradually created a rift between the two groups. However, what was even more noticeable was the cultural and language divide causing breakdown in communication, frustration, tension, and for some Australian actors, alienation. But for all of this personal drama which took place, when the production finally arrived in Australia, tolerance, understanding, and a new found respect developed between the directors and actors of both countries, with friendships being formed and the language barrier being broken down. Filmed partly in Bulgaria and partly in Australia, in English and Bulgarian (with English subtitles). Also features music by Petrunka (The Melburne Women’s Bulgarian Choir) conducted by Bagryana Popov. Narrated by Alex Menglet.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Seahorse Productions, Australian Film Commission, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Pippa Bailey
results.description: A very interesting documentary about an artistic collaboration between Australia and Bulgaria involving the Hildegard Theatre Company from Melbourne, Australia and a group of Bulgarian actors led by avant garde theatre director Vaskressia Vicharova in Bulgaria. The Hildegard Theatre Company’s passion for Bulgarian folklore inspired them to initiate a joint production of bi-lingual theatre to travel Australia during 1996 - their choice of performance being the heroic legend of “Inje” a fearless war-lord and bandit. Angela Campbell and Bagryana Popov, artistic directors for Hildegard, and David Wicks, theatre director, headed the Australian company in Bulgaria where the collaboration suffered enormously during the rehearsal process. Differences in interpretation of the narrative, directing methods, and acting methods gradually created a rift between the two groups. However, what was even more noticeable was the cultural and language divide causing breakdown in communication, frustration, tension, and for some Australian actors, alienation. But for all of this personal drama which took place, when the production finally arrived in Australia, tolerance, understanding, and a new found respect developed between the directors and actors of both countries, with friendships being formed and the language barrier being broken down. Filmed partly in Bulgaria and partly in Australia, in English and Bulgarian (with English subtitles). Also features music by Petrunka (The Melburne Women’s Bulgarian Choir) conducted by Bagryana Popov. Narrated by Alex Menglet.
description_for_label: A very interesting documentary about an artistic collaboration between Australia and Bulgaria involving the Hildegard Theatre Company from Melbourne, Australia and a group of Bulgarian actors led by avant garde theatre director Vaskressia Vicharova in Bulgaria. The Hildegard Theatre Company’s passion for Bulgarian folklore inspired them to initiate a joint production of bi-lingual theatre to travel Australia during 1996 - their choice of performance being the heroic legend of “Inje” a fearless war-lord and bandit. Angela Campbell and Bagryana Popov, artistic directors for Hildegard, and David Wicks, theatre director, headed the Australian company in Bulgaria where the collaboration suffered enormously during the rehearsal process. Differences in interpretation of the narrative, directing methods, and acting methods gradually created a rift between the two groups. However, what was even more noticeable was the cultural and language divide causing breakdown in communication, frustration, tension, and for some Australian actors, alienation. But for all of this personal drama which took place, when the production finally arrived in Australia, tolerance, understanding, and a new found respect developed between the directors and actors of both countries, with friendships being formed and the language barrier being broken down. Filmed partly in Bulgaria and partly in Australia, in English and Bulgarian (with English subtitles). results.title: Inja = Dog
results.creator_credit: Joe Weatherstone, Steve Pasvolsky and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
South Africa, 1980s. Using a young Xhosa boy as a pawn, a farmer teaches his puppy to be white man’s best friend. Ten years later, both their lives hang in the balance at the mercy of the dog.
Filmed on location at Bien Donne Werf, Franschhoek Valley, South Africa.
In English/Afrikaans/Xhosa with English subtitles
